message: In-law said it will fry it so thats why wondering
Voltage is the same (5v) and current is an on demand thing. The iPad charge will provide up to 2.1 amps if needed but the iPod will only draw a maximum of 1amp... Birthing to worry about
Apple should just start making one charger now that everyone is going to have both an iPhone and iPad.

The iPad needs 10w to charge, versus an iPod or iPhone, which only needs 5w. Having said that, 10w is the maximum rating and the device being charged (say, the iPod) will draw only the amount of current required by it. So, charging your iPod with an iPad charger should be quite safe.
From Apple's website for the replacement iPad 10W USB Power Adapter... "It also charges iPhone and all iPod models with a dock connector."
Maybe it's a misperception, but my iPhone seems to charge faster with the iPad adapter.
@paff That's my experience, too. Haven't really timed it, though.

I prefer not to mix the two after a friend's apartment was burned down because of an iPod charger.  It probably was a freak accident but since then I don't leave any chargers plugged in the wall once I'm finished with them. I also don't use the iPad charger with my iPhone as it heats up too quickly.
@marle What heats up too quickly? Your iPhone or your iPad charger? Last one should heat up less when charging an iPhone because it needs less power.
I've only used one power adapter for both the iPhone and iPad since I got an iPad a year ago. The iPad charger works fine with the iPhone, original and 3GS. Absolutely no ill effects.
The iPod will charger faster, I have experience, and it should be safe.
